page.title: 02Landscape N.E. of Baldock
page.content:
This block is mainly undulating chalk country, where the Chilterns merge with the East Anglian Heights.
All the land is between 50-100 metres above sea level and the chalk is usually covered by a thin layer of glacial till (boulder clay) brought by ice sheets from the Midlands during the Ice Age.
A small dry valley cuts E-W across the block and the London-Cambridge railway uses two smaller dry valleys to cut through a spur of land which rises to 96 metres at Bygrave.
The only surface stream is the headwaters of the River Ivel in the S.W. square of the area, where it runs out of Baldock.
